title: The Question Everyone's Afraid to Ask
subtitle: What is Christianity when you strip away the bumper stickers?
teaser: Most people have opinions about Christianity. Fewer have asked what it actually claims.
theme: Christianity has been buried under cultural assumptions — Paul's letter to the Galatians begins by stripping them away

emphasis: which is really no gospel at all
modules.passage: I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you to live in the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel — which is really no gospel at all. Evidently some people are throwing you into confusion and are trying to pervert the gospel of Christ.
modules.fullPassage: I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you to live in the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel — which is really no gospel at all. Evidently some people are throwing you into confusion and are trying to pervert the gospel of Christ. But even if we or an angel from heaven should preach a gospel other than the one we preached to you, let them be under God's curse! As we have already said, so now I say again: If anybody is preaching to you a gospel other than what you accepted, let them be under God's curse!

modules.meaning: good news, gospel — a public announcement of something that has happened, not advice about something you should do
modules.rootMeaning: In the Roman Empire, euangelion was a political term before it was a religious one. When Caesar won a battle or a new emperor was enthroned, heralds would carry the euangelion — the 'good news' — to every city. It announced a new reality that was already true whether you believed it or not. Paul deliberately borrowed this imperial vocabulary to make a subversive claim: the real king is not in Rome.
modules.usageNote: Paul uses euangelion 60 times in his letters. When he says the Galatians are turning to a 'different gospel,' the Greek word is heteros — meaning 'a gospel of a fundamentally different kind.' He then corrects himself: it is 'really no gospel at all.' A message that requires your performance to complete it is not news. It is a to-do list.

relatedWords.reference: To announce good news (G2097) — the verb form. To 'evangelize' originally meant to herald a reality, not to recruit converts.

modules.definition: A public announcement of a new reality — not instructions for self-improvement, but news of something that has already occurred
modules.usage: Paul's entire argument in Galatians hinges on this word. If Christianity is euangelion — news — then it reports what God has done. If it is nomos — law — then it demands what you must do. These are not the same category.

modules.heading: A Letter Written in Anger
modules.body:
Most letters in the ancient world opened with a compliment. Paul's letters to other churches follow this convention: 'I thank my God every time I remember you' (Philippians). 'I always thank my God for you' (1 Corinthians). The social expectation was clear — you flattered your audience before making your argument.

Galatians skips the pleasantries entirely. After a brief greeting, Paul writes: 'I am astonished.' The Greek word is thaumazo — a term of shock, bewilderment, almost incredulity. He cannot believe what he is hearing from Galatia.

The problem was not that the Galatians had abandoned Christianity. The problem was subtler and more dangerous: they had modified it. Teachers had arrived in Galatia after Paul's departure — likely from Jerusalem, likely with credentials — and they had offered what sounded like a reasonable upgrade. 'You believe in Jesus? Wonderful. Now complete the process. Follow the law of Moses. Get circumcised. Keep the dietary codes. Faith gets you in the door, but Torah observance makes you a real member of the family.'

Paul does not treat this as a minor theological disagreement. He treats it as a category error — the difference between news and advice, between gift and payment, between freedom and a more sophisticated form of slavery.

This distinction matters because most people who have rejected Christianity have not actually rejected the euangelion. They have rejected a version of it — the version that is really a performance system wearing religious clothes. The 'different gospel' Paul warns about is alive and well: behave correctly, believe the right things, clean yourself up, and maybe God will accept you.

That is not what Paul preached. What Paul preached was closer to a war dispatch than a self-help book: something has happened. A rescue operation has been launched. The only question is whether you will receive the news.

modules.title: Inherited Faith and the Hollywood Furnace
modules.body:
Dennis Quaid grew up Baptist in Houston, Texas. He has spoken about this without bitterness but also without nostalgia — it was the faith of his family, the wallpaper of his upbringing, something absorbed rather than chosen. By the time he left for Hollywood in his early twenties, that inherited faith had not been tested against anything.

Hollywood tested everything. Quaid arrived with talent — genuine talent — and the industry confirmed it quickly. 'Breaking Away' in 1979. 'The Right Stuff' in 1983. By his late twenties he was a leading man in major films, surrounded by the machinery of celebrity: money, access, recognition, and a culture that treated excess as a lifestyle rather than a warning sign.

The inherited Baptist faith did not survive contact with this world. Not because it was disproven, but because it had never been proven — it was assumption, not conviction. Quaid drifted away from churchgoing the way most people do: not with a dramatic rejection but with a gradual replacement. Sunday mornings gave way to Saturday nights. The rhythms of faith were overwritten by the rhythms of ambition.

This is the part of the story that does not make the highlight reel. There was no crisis of faith. There was something more common and more insidious: faith that had never become personal slowly becoming irrelevant. The hole it left was not immediately visible. Success papered over it for years.

But the hole was there. And Quaid would eventually try to fill it with cocaine — not because he was weak, but because the inherited answers had stopped reaching the actual questions his life was asking.

modules.connectionToTheme: Quaid's inherited faith mirrors the Galatians' confusion — a version of Christianity that was culturally received rather than personally encountered. When Paul warns about a 'different gospel,' he is warning about exactly this: a secondhand religion that looks right but has no power to meet the real questions.
modules.heading: Inherited Faith and the Hollywood Furnace
The Difference Between News and Advice
modules.body:
There is a distinction that matters more than most theological categories: the distinction between news and advice.

Advice tells you what to do. It assumes the outcome depends on your effort. 'Eat better. Exercise more. Pray harder. Be more spiritual.' Advice is conditional — if you follow it, things might improve. If you do not, that is on you.

News tells you what has happened. It reports a reality that exists whether you act on it or not. 'The war is over. The hostages have been freed. The debt has been cancelled.' News does not depend on your performance. It depends on what someone else has done.

Paul's argument in Galatians is that Christianity belongs in the second category. The euangelion is not a self-help program. It is an announcement: something has happened in the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus that has changed the terms of reality. You did not cause it. You cannot undo it. You can only receive it or ignore it.

The Judaizers were converting news back into advice. 'Yes, something happened. But now here is what YOU need to do.' Paul considered this not just wrong but destructive — a reversion to the very system that the euangelion had dismantled.

This distinction is the reason Christianity has always been difficult to categorize. It does not fit neatly into 'religion' as most people define the term — a system of moral rules and spiritual practices. At its core, Christianity is a claim about something that occurred in history. The question is not 'Will you follow these rules?' The question is 'Do you believe this actually happened?'

modules.historicalContext: The word euangelion would have carried immediate political overtones for Paul's first-century audience. Roman imperial inscriptions used the same word to announce Caesar's victories and decrees. The Priene Calendar Inscription (9 BC) declared Augustus's birthday 'the beginning of good news (euangelion) for the world.' Paul's use of this word was not accidental — it was a direct challenge to imperial claims of authority and salvation.
modules.fascinatingFact: Galatians is likely Paul's earliest letter — possibly written around 48-49 AD, less than two decades after the crucifixion. This means the argument about whether Christianity is news or advice is not a modern debate. It is the original debate, the one the church had to resolve before it could become anything else.

modules.ancientTruth: Paul opened his letter to the Galatians by distinguishing the euangelion — an announcement of what God has done — from a 'different gospel' that turned good news back into a performance system requiring human effort to complete.
modules.modernApplication: The version of Christianity most visible in Western culture — moralistic, performance-driven, politically entangled — is often the 'different gospel' Paul warned about. Many people who say they have rejected Christianity have actually rejected this counterfeit. The original claim remains largely unexamined.
modules.connectionPoint: Paul's Galatians were not rejecting Christ. They were adding requirements to grace. The result looked like religion but functioned like slavery. The same pattern repeats whenever Christianity becomes primarily about behavior modification rather than an encounter with a person and a claim about history.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Jesus himself drew this distinction: 'You study the Scriptures diligently because you think that in them you have eternal life. These are the very Scriptures that testify about me, yet you refuse to come to me to have life.' (John 5:39-40) — The religious system points to a person. Mistaking the system for the person is the original 'different gospel.'

modules.prompt: When you think of Christianity, what comes to mind first — a set of rules and behaviors, or a claim about something that happened? Where did that association come from?
additionalQuestions: If Christianity is 'news' rather than 'advice,' how does that change what it would mean to engage with it honestly?
Have you ever rejected — or been drawn to — something that turned out to be a counterfeit version of the real thing? What was the giveaway?

Dennis Quaid's faith was inherited but untested. Is there a belief or assumption in your life that falls into that category — something you hold (or have discarded) without ever having truly examined it?

modules.prayerText: God — I am not sure how to address you, or whether anyone is listening. But I am here, and I am willing to ask a question I have avoided: what is Christianity, actually? Not the version I absorbed from culture or rejected out of frustration, but the thing itself. If Paul was right — if there is a real gospel buried under the counterfeits — I want to see it. I am not making promises. I am not signing up for anything. I am just asking. And if that is enough to start, then I am starting. Amen.

modules.commitment: Today I will hold one question without rushing to answer it: What if the Christianity I think I know is not the Christianity that actually exists? I will sit with that uncertainty honestly, without defending my current position or abandoning it.
leavingAtCross: The assumption that I already know what Christianity is based on cultural exposure alone
The reflexive dismissal or acceptance that comes from never having examined the original claim
The idea that the version of faith I inherited or rejected is the only version that exists
receivingFromCross: Permission to ask the question honestly without knowing where it leads
The possibility that there is a gospel underneath the performance religion
The beginning of curiosity rather than certainty — which may be the more honest place to start
modules.content: Today I will hold one question without rushing to answer it: What if the Christianity I think I know is not the Christianity that actually exists? I will sit with that uncertainty honestly, without defending my current position or abandoning it.

forReflection: Why does Paul skip the usual compliments at the beginning of Galatians? What does his tone tell you about how seriously he views the situation?
What is the difference between euangelion (news) and the 'different gospel' the Judaizers were preaching? Why does Paul consider this distinction life-or-death?
How does Dennis Quaid's experience of inherited faith illustrate the kind of Christianity that cannot withstand real testing?
forAccountabilityPartners: Share honestly: what is your default mental image of Christianity? A set of rules, a community, a historical claim, something else entirely?
Ask each other: have you ever encountered the 'news' version of Christianity, or has your experience been primarily the 'advice' version?
Discuss: what would it take for you to genuinely reexamine something you thought you had already figured out?

relatedScriptures.text: You study the Scriptures diligently because you think that in them you have eternal life. These are the very Scriptures that testify about me, yet you refuse to come to me to have life.
Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, who gave himself for our sins to rescue us from the present evil age, according to the will of our God and Father.
For I am not ashamed of the gospel, because it is the power of God that brings salvation to everyone who believes: first to the Jew, then to the Gentile.

forDeeperStudy.title: Galatians 1
forDeeperStudy.note: Read the full opening chapter — notice how Paul establishes his credentials not through institutional authority but through direct encounter with Christ. His gospel did not come through a committee.

modules.name: Paul of Tarsus
modules.title: The Apostle Who Destroyed the Church Before He Built It
modules.description: Before he wrote Galatians, Paul was the early church's most dangerous enemy. A Pharisee trained under Gamaliel, he had impeccable religious credentials and used them to systematically persecute Christians. His conversion on the Damascus Road was not a gradual warming to Jesus — it was a violent disruption of everything he believed. He went from arresting believers to becoming one, and the resulting theology was forged in the gap between performance and grace. He understood legalism from the inside because he had been its most accomplished practitioner.
modules.keyQuote: Am I now trying to win the approval of human beings, or of God? Or am I trying to please people? If I were still trying to please people, I would not be a servant of Christ.
modules.lessonForUs: Paul's authority to dismantle performance religion came from having been its greatest champion. He did not criticize legalism as an outsider — he criticized it as a recovering addict. His letter to the Galatians carries the weight of someone who tried the performance system at the highest level and found it bankrupt.
